data.title: Expose autofocus configuration settings
data.body: Resolves https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/27352

data.title: Expose autofocus configuration settings
data.body:
### Problem

Currently, extensions that open the quick open are forced to autofocus the first element. There is no way to specify which item should be highlighted in a quick open menu when calling `showQuickPick`. This is problematic when using the quick open to navigate forwards or backwards in a stack of quick open menus for content drill down because the user loses their place in a larger list.

### Solution

Add `IAutoFocus` options to `vscode.d.ts` file and add optional property to `QuickOpenOptions`. A possible nice to have would be to add another options for `autoFocusQuickPickItem` that accepts a quick pick item and reveals it in the tree.

data.title: Task Quick Open Sort Order

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
With the TSC task provider, I was trying to get the `tsconfig.json` for the current file to always show up first in the `tsc` section of the `task` quick open. Even if I return the tasks in the expected order, it looks like they are sorted by name: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/tasks/browser/quickOpen.ts#L69

Is there a way to control the sort order within a group?

data.title: Test: Webviews / Markdown Preview Preserve Scroll Position
data.body:
Test for #22995 

**Complexity**
2

**OS**
- [x] Linux @dbaeumer 
- [x] Mac @isidorn 
- [x] Windows @waderyan 

----

**Release Notes**
1. Open the release notes in the editor.
1. Scroll midway down the page.
1. Switch editors to hide the release notes and then switch back. Verify we restore the previous scroll position
1. Try opening the release notes in other groups. Scroll position should be saved and restored per group

**Markdown Preview**
1. Open a long markdown document
1. Open the preview
1. Scroll down through the preview then switch away from the preview
1. Switch back to the preview and ensure position is restored
1. Try opening multiple previews in other groups
1. Try making sure scroll sync and other settings work as expected

**Extension**
1. Install the svg viewer extension: https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=cssho.vscode-svgviewer
1. Preview an svg document
1. Make sure the svg preview work as expected
1. Try switching back and forth between the svg preview and moving it between editor groups

data.title: Test: TSC Task Provider
data.body:
Test for #26079

**Complexity**
2

**OS**
- [x] Linux @bpasero
- [x] Mac @waderyan 
- [x] Windows @dbaeumer  

**Setup**
Create a simple workspace that has a `.vscode/tasks` of 

```
{
    "version": "2.0.0"
}
```

**Scenarios**
1. Create a `tsconfig.json` in your workspace.
1. Run the `Run task` command
1. Ensure that a task for `tsconfig.json` is shown
1. Create a simple ts file and try building using the task. Check that errors are reported

1. Try running the build task. This should also build the `tsconfig.json`
1. Try creating multiple `tsconfig.json` in sub folders and with names such as `tsconfig.app.json`. You should now see task for each `tsconfig.json`. The build task should build all of these.

1. Try setting `"typescript.tsc.autoDetect": "off"`. Ensure that tsc tasks no longer show up

data.title: Dvorak - QWERTY ⌘: show in finder command has wrong shortcut

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: - VSCode Version: Version 1.12.2 (1.12.2) - OS Version: 10.12.5 (16F73) Steps to Reproduce: 1. Set keyboard layout to Dvorak - QWERTY ⌘ 1. Press ⌘-option-R, the command listed in the right-click menu Nothing happens. However, if I press ⌘-option-O, it opens the file in the finder. O happens to be the label on the physical keyboard key that that is labeled R in the regular Dvorak keyboard mapping. Dvorak - QWERTY ⌘ means that when ⌘ is down, it should use the regular qwerty keyboard map.

data.title: Go files not using 4 Space indentation specified in settings.json
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:16:25.899Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 3.10.0-327.36.3.el7.x86_64
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|java|redhat|0.4.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:
I have my settings.json with these values:
{
    "editor.minimap.enabled": true,
    "editor.formatOnSave": true,
    "java.errors.incompleteClasspath.severity": "ignore",
    "git.ignoreLegacyWarning": true,
    "workbench.colorTheme": "Default Light+",
    "editor.detectIndentation": false,
    "editor.insertSpaces": true,
    "editor.tabSize": 4
}
1. Open any *.go file, in the tab information says "Tab Size: 4"
2. Open any other file type (txt, java, etc) it says "Spaces 4" which is what I want.

I've tried this with and without go extension.

data.title: Ctrl + e in integrated terminal (bash) when focused brings up command drop down
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Bring up the Integrated terminal
2. Make sure its in focus (By clicking on it and typing something in maybe)
3. Type at least 1 character in to make sure that end-of-input and beginning-of-input are not the same character
4. Place cursor before end-of-input with the left arrow, optionally by using Hit Ctrl + a to confirm that the go-to-beginning-of-input shortcut actually works
5. Hit Ctrl + e 

Expected Result:
When the integrated terminal is focused, the cursor goes to the end of the input (As it would in bash)

Actual Result:
The command dropdown appears and the integrated terminal is unfocused.

data.title: Let the task framework configure 'Press any key to close the terminal'
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: master

I demoed the new task support to @egamma and he was confused about the message since it sounds very equal to a message shown in the cmd.exe when running a bat file. Especially since the user has no hint to know that the terminal will be reused and feels obligated to press a key to close the terminal.

Since we need to experiment a little with the message it would be best if we could customize the message.

data.title: Allow disable/uninstall of a "soft" dependency in an Extension Pack
data.body:
I created a "meta" extension pack that is simply a combination of other extensions.  https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=johnpapa.angular-essentials

In this case, someone may want to disable or uninstall one of these, which is not supported. I assume this is because the meta extension may actually depend on it. 

I propose that extension packs have an option to designate soft dependencies, so we can create these meta extension packs and let users consume them and disable/uninstall ones they don't want.

cc @chrisdias

data.title: Problemd with @import in scss files
data.body:
When editting an scss file I get errors simillar to the following in the OUTPUT panel:
```
node:23028) UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Unhandled promise rejection (rejection id: 1): 
Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, stat 'c:\\materialblend\lib\themes\core\variables.scss'
```
This is because `_variables.scss` is a partial scss file. The `@import` statement importing the file is
`@import("variables")` and not `@import("_variables")`.  The sass compiler traditionally finds the partials
but VSCode has difficulty with this.

Is there a workaround for this, except for changing my `@import` statements?

data.title: Npm module debug not showing up in vscode debugging console
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version:  Debian Stretch

Steps to Reproduce:

1. make app.js

```
    'use strict';
    var debug = require('debug')('myapp:test');
    console.log('DEBUG is', process.env.DEBUG);
    console.log('NODE_ENV is', process.env.NODE_ENV);
    debug("foo");
```

2. in vscode left panel click on DEBUG and configure launch.json

```
    {
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "Programm starten",
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/app.js",
      "protocol": "inspector",
      "env": {
        "DEBUG":"myapp:*",
        "NODE_ENV": "development"
      }
    }
```

3. click on green arrow (Start debug) will show only

    DEBUG is myapp:*
    NODE_ENV is development

4. on console (or even in vscode terminal) the following command will give full output (in color! yeah)

```
    $ DEBUG="myapp:*" node app.js

    DEBUG is myapp:*
    NODE_ENV is development
    myapp:test foo +0ms
```

Conclusion: There is no information from npm debug module, when started via debug.

Remark: NODE_ENV variable is not necessary, but I wanted to rule out, that debug will not be blocked, by thinking it is in production...

data.title: File save-as always fails on first attempt

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:20:36.315Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|Bookmarks|alefragnani|0.15.0|
|numbered-bookmarks|alefragnani|0.9.1|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.2|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.10.0|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|1.1.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new file 
2. Use File/Save -as to save it in a project

I _always_ see this initial error....

Failed to save 'Persist.cpp': A system error occured (EBUSY: resource busy or locked, open 'c:\... path......\Persist.cpp')

3. Click retry - the file will be saved successfully.

I'm using git for source control - maybe there's a race condition here but this error happens consistently on two different machines across multiple projects.

data.title: Better editor titles for generic file names
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2

When working with generically named files (such as index.js/ts on a node project), it's unhelpful for that to be the main text displayed on the editor tab/Open Editors section. 

At present, the folder name is hinted subtly if more than one editor with the generic name is open, but a better solution for generics would be to highlight the folder name, with the title hinted instead.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5188481/26492003/e8af44b2-4209-11e7-93b5-d3ea2032a899.png)
suggestion along lines of: 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5188481/26492312/4c5cf9cc-420b-11e7-9fa7-e8abe10ee5e1.png)

(apologies for inconsistent slashes and folder names; I got distracted!)

data.title: Feature request - multi monitor support
data.body: I've become a bit spoilt by the multi-monitor and 'layout' support in Visual Studio.  Is there any chance we could get multi-monitor support (even if basic) in VsCode?  For example, i'd like to be able to drag the Output or Problems tab to a different monitor.
